body.p:
Sunday night: March 2: Again, late: It will betwelve before I
sleep. A strange, stopped day: Ted + I having morning coffee-
black + bitter-edged, with the Bramwells in their uncomfortable
second-flor flat, chairs turned wrond-side-to, records scattered,
white marble free place angular + functionless. James is
leaving for their home in France tomorrow. Ted met him in
the library yesterday, a few seconds before I came into the
periodical room from my last class of the week: I looked
into the room throught the glass door before I opened it, saw no
black coated Ted, pushed the door open, saw James' back in
brown, white tweed coat then Ted, dark, disheveled + with
that queer eletric invisible radiance he gives off as he
did that first day I saw him over two years ago: to think,
irony of , that two years ago I was feverishly studying
Websterfor my supervisions (which very plays I
am this week examinging my students on and furiously,
desperately, taling myself into a crazy belief that I would
somehow mange to see Ted + imprint my markineffacably
on him before he left for Australia and murder his pale
freckled mistres named Shirley. let all rivals forever
be called Shirley. How, now sitting here in the calme clared
livingroom where we have own ordered teas, I feel I have
wrested chaos and despair - and all the mwasteful
accident of life - into a rich and meaninfgful pattern - The light trhough this door, into the dark dum pink-walled
dining alcove, shires to our bedroom + bright from
his writing of poems in the swept spacious bedroom
the chink of light through the crack in between the doorframe
+ door betrays him to me: + suddenly all, is most, of
that long 35 page chapter which should be - the
evenets at leas - the core of my novel, seem cheap
easily come-by-all that sensational jabber about
winds + doors + walls balging away and back.
But that was the psychic equivante of the whole

experience: how does Woolf do it? How does Lawrence do
it? I come down to learn of those two: Lawrence,
because of the rich physical passion,- fields of foces -
and the real presence of leaves and earth and beasts
and weathers, sap-rich, and Woolf because of tha
almost sexless neurotic luminousness - The cathing
of objects: chairs, tables + the figures on a street
corer, and the infusion of radiance: a shimmer
of the plasm that is life. I cannot must not copy
either. God knows what tone I shall strike. Close to
a prose-poem of balanced, cadence words and
meanings, of street-corners and lights and people,
but not merely romantic; not marely
not merely a diary: not, ostensibily, autobiographic:
in one year I must so this experience in
my mind, it with distance, create cool shrewd
views of it, so that it becomes reshapen. All this -
digression: James, the subject: yesterday, a broken man,
his craggy sallow face, with its look of genial
black lines - hair, brows wrinkles + dark grain of
shawed beard, his bright balck eyes - all
seemed broken, askew, Tedsaid his hand was weak
and cold as snails. when are you leaving America?"
I felt impelled to ask first, meaning, of course, when
in summer. "Monday", e said. He cant work here, cant
write here. He taled loudly, in an audible whisper if I
wanted to quiet him, I get out of there, with the dilly
girls listening over their periodicals. A chink opened into
his heel: shat it must be to decide him to leave, +
how absurdly vindicated I felt, remembering Joan
mean-tuned "Why are you going? - Dont you like it
here?" How can James leave her? This always puzzles me,
I need Ted to smell + kiss + sleep + read by as I
need bread + wine. I like James; ine of the few men here

whose life' doesn't seem aavailable, processe in uniform,
callophane-wrapped blocks, like synthetic orange cheese:
James has the authentic, cave-aged, mold-ripened smess of
The real thing. And yet, not a man, not completely. Joan
seems young + then for him. At coffee this morning he
seemed restored, jovial. We talked of bulls + bullfights,
after the two movies - on Goya + bullighting - last night.
I borrowed James autobiography + finished it tonight:
750 pages, "The Unfinished Man" - about his experiences as
a conscientious objector during the war: desultory
beginning, here, there, Stockolm, Finland + all told about,
characters pos trayed, not actually moving + talling on
their own, but talked about, half-emerged, like a of
flushed marble. And women: he seem to from them -
his wife queerly in the background, diminuishing to
America, to divorse; his child evaporating. "A told-about"
love affair' with' a queer Finnish girl, death-oriented, who
commits suicide (was he to blame, partly? did it really
happen?) and a rather illuminating statement that
he ("like most men") believes that loving a woman
eternally isn't incompatible with leaving her: loving, leaving-
a lovely consunance. I don't see it: and my man doesn't,
The quiet of midnight settlesover Route q. Already it is
tomorrow + the days I cross off with such vicious glee,-
just as I toss, with premature eagerness, empty bottles
of wine + honey' into the waste basket be near +
clear of clogging half-full jais-are those of my youngness
+ my promise. I believe, whether in madness or in half-
truth that if I live' for a year with the two years of my
life + learning . at Cambler age I can write + rewrite a
good novel. Ten times this 35 page chapter + rewriting +
rewriting'. Goal set: June 1959: a novel + book of
poems, I can not draw in James' drama: war, , parachute doprs, hospitals in trenhces - my womans
